Package com.sap.conn.jco.server

Contains the interfaces and factories for the RFC server functionality.

See:
          Description

Interface Summary
JCoServer The JCoServer interface provides access to the public APIs in the JCo server implementation.
JCoServerAuthorizationData Authorization parameters sent by the caller system JCoServerAuthorizationData will be passed to the JCoSecurityHandler, if ones is installed, on each call.
JCoServerCallHandlerFactory JCoServerCallHandlerFactory is the base interface for the JCoServerFunctionHandlerFactory and JCoServerRequestHandlerFactory.
JCoServerContext JCoServerContext provides additional information for the remote call
JCoServerContextInfo JCoServerContextInfo provides additional information of the remote system and the context of the request.
JCoServerErrorListener Listener interface for the errors occurred inside of the JCoServer.
JCoServerExceptionListener Listener interface for the exceptions occurred inside of the JCoServer in the JCo runtime.
JCoServerFunctionHandler Interface for the function handler.
JCoServerFunctionHandlerFactory Factory for creating function handlers for a server instance.
JCoServerRequestHandler Interface for the request handler.
JCoServerRequestHandlerFactory Factory for creating request handlers for a server instance.
JCoServerRunnable Interface marker for the runnable-s used by the JCo server internally.
JCoServerSecurityHandler Security Handler will be asked to check the permissions of the user, who initiated a remote call.
JCoServerStateChangedListener JCo server state change listener interface.
JCoServerThreadStarter Interface can be implemented by the infrastructure within an application server.
JCoServerTIDHandler This interface defines methods to handle transactions being received from an SAP system.
JCoServerUnitIDHandler This interface defines methods to handle a function unit received by a JCoServer.
 

Class Summary
DefaultServerHandlerFactory<T> This class is the base for a trivial default implementation of JCoServerFunctionHandlerFactory and JCoServerRequestHandlerFactory.
DefaultServerHandlerFactory.FunctionHandlerFactory Trivial implementation for JCoServerFunctionHandlerFactory.
DefaultServerHandlerFactory.RequestHandlerFactory Trivial implementation for JCoServerRequestHandlerFactory.
JCoServerFactory Factory for creating server instances used by JCo applications.
 

Enum Summary
JCoServerCallType Describes all types of requests a server can receive via RFC from the ABAP client.
JCoServerState JCoServerState reflects the possible states of a JCoServer.
 

Exception Summary
JCoApplicationAuthorizationException Using this exception the application's security handler notifies the sender system, that the user, who initiated a remote call, does not have enough permissions
 

Package com.sap.conn.jco.server Description

Contains the interfaces and factories for the RFC server functionality. The package covers both parts: infrastructure related interfaces as well as interfaces that are typically used by business applications for implementing the functionality of RFC-enabled Java function modules. Some of them cannot be assigned clearly whether these are part of the infrastructure or of the custom application. But a rough specification could be done as follows:

1. Business application related:
  • Call handlers: The request and function handlers. This is where a custom application implements the business logic.
  • JCoServerContext and JCoServerContextInfo: Can be used by a custom application for getting information about the current request context, in particular also about the caller system.
2. Infrastructure related:
  • All server event listeners: The error, exception and server state change listeners.
  • TID and UnitID handlers: Deal with the "exactly once" (EO) semantics of tRfc/qRfc and bgRfc function calls.
  • JCoServerRunnable and JCoServerThreadStarter: Provide the thread environment in which RFC-enabled Java function modules are executed. Sometimes an application server requires certain Thread subclasses for starting and managing threads.
3. Runtime environment or use case dependent:
  • JCoServerFactory and JCoServer: Central factory and main server interface for working with RFC servers.
  • Call handler factories: Decide which specific function or request handler shall process an incoming RFC request. The provided default implementation classes by JCo are the easiest variant to use for small application scenarios.
  • JCoServerSecurityHandler: Allows to do potential authorization checks before an incoming RFC request will be dispatched to a call handler.

Recommendations:

  • In an application server environment, only a single CallHandlerFactory should be used which is provided by a central infrastructure component. If suitable, this can also be the default implementation provided by JCo.
  • All components which need to be implemented but cannot be clearly assigned to the infrastructure or business application part (case 3), should be implemented by the infrastructure team.
    In an application server environment, a business application should only deal with the minimum interface set of the RFC server functionality. How an RFC-enabled Java function module needs to be implemented should then be defined by the application server infrastructure.

Note:
The implementations for the following interfaces in this package are exclusively provided by the JCo runtime: JCoServer, JCoServerAuthorizationData, JCoServerContext, JCoServerContextInfo, and JCoServerRunnable.
Custom implementations of these interfaces are not supported. Hence, adding a new method to these interfaces is not considered as an incompatible change.
All other interfaces in this package are designed for being implemented by custom Java applications and custom environment specific infrastructure components.
